question: If apgar score is 6, at 5 minutes of life, then what is the interpretation:
exp: According to NNF & WHO: APGAR SCORE INTERPRETATION 0-3 Severe bih asphyxia 4-7 Moderate bih asphyxia >7 Normal

question: Most common cause of syncope in a child?
exp: Syncope is sudden transient loss of consciousness with inability to maintain postural tone - Syncope is caused by a lack of adequate cerebral blood flow - Most common cause of syncope in the normal pediatric population is neurocardiogenic syncope, which is also known as vasovagal syncope.

question: Most common cardiac defect in turner syndrome:
exp: --> Overall MC congenital heart disease in Turner syndrome is Bicuspid aoic valve --> 2nd MC congenital heart disease in Turner syndrome is Coarctation of aoa TURNER SYNDROME: - Basic defect is 45 X0 - Always seen in Females IMPOANT FEATURES (MNEMONIC - SeeA Baby CLOWN) - Sho stature, Sensorineural hearing loss, Sho 4th metacarpal - Amenorrhea (Primary) - Barr body absent - Cardiac anomalies, Cystic hygroma - Lymphedema of hand and feet, Low thyroid - Ovaries Underdeveloped (Streak Ovaries) --> thus infeile. - Webbed neck - Nipples widely placed, Shield shaped chest, No intellectual disability

question: All of the followings are classic triad for congenital rubella syndrome; except:
Bidextrous approach at what age?
exp: 3 months - Holds an object when placed in hands 4 months - Tries to reach for an object, but overshoots 5 months - Bidextrous grasp 6 months - Unidextrous/palmar grasp

question: Turricephaly is:
exp: Turricephaly is cone shaped head from premature fusion of the coronal, sphenofrontal & frontoethmoidal stures. - It's a type of craniosynostosis (MC type of craniosynostosis is DOLICOCEPHALY) Abnormality Debscription Dolicocephaly (scaphocephaly) Premature closure of sagittal suture Long and narrow skull Most common form of craniosynostosis Trigoncephaly Premature fusion of metopic suture Keel-shaped forehead and hypotelorism Increased risk of forebrain abnormalities Plagiocephaly Asymmetrical flattening of 1 side of the skull

question: Child able to draw a cross at which age?
exp: 4 years - Copies a rectangle or cross or plus sign Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics clearly states child copies cross at 48 months i. e. 4 years of age So the answer is option A: 4 years

question: Late complication of diphtheria:
exp: Late Complications of diphtheria Cardiac Neurologic Myocarditis Congestive cardiac failure Arrhythmias Palatal paralysis - nasal quality in voice, difficulty in swallowing & risk of aspiration (2 weeks) Ocular palsy (3 weeks) Symmetric polyneuropathy (10 days- 3 months)

question: Child able to make tower of 5-6 cubes at which age?
exp: 15 months - Tower of 2 cubes 18 months - Tower of 4 cubes 21 months - Tower of 5-6 cubes 24 months - Tower of 6-7 cubes 3 years - Makes a BRIDGE of3 cubes 4 years - Makes a GATE of 5 cubes
